metadata.project_title: Centering Community Needs in Energy Equity
metadata.research_question: Which types of groups face historic disinvestment, high energy burdens, and limited access to the clean economy? How can social programs center lived experiences and partner with trusted CBOs to ensure solutions align with real needs?

key_findings.summary: Black, Indigenous, rural, and low-income households face the highest energy burdens and historic disinvestment. Successful programs partner with trusted community-based organizations to deliver door-to-door outreach, flexible funding, and integrated health-energy solutions that align with community needs and strengthen local economies.

energy_burden_and_equity.description: Black, Indigenous, rural, and low-income households face disproportionate energy burdens
key_points: Energy burdens as high as 16.8% of income for low-income households vs. 3.5% for general population
Black and female-headed renter households bearing disproportionate costs
Older homes often require pre-upgrade repairs, exacerbating energy inefficiencies
Historic disinvestment, redlining, and exclusion from mainstream energy programs exacerbate disparities
Targeted interventions reduced energy burdens by 10‚Äì91%

cbo_partnership_models.description: Community-based organizations are central to program design, outreach, and delivery
key_points: CBOs serve as trusted messengers and cultural brokers
Effective collaborations between CBOs, local governments, and technical experts
Challenges with staffing, funding, and technical expertise within CBOs
Selection based on existing community trust and representation most successful

housing_stock_challenges.description: Older, inefficient, and poorly maintained housing stock is a major barrier
key_points: Many programs require pre-upgrade repairs (lead abatement, structural fixes)
Split incentives between landlords and tenants complicate upgrades in rental housing
Successful strategies integrate health and energy interventions
Flexible funding (block grants) and landlord incentives help address barriers

community_engagement.description: Centering lived experience and community engagement is key to program effectiveness
key_points: Methods include peer-to-peer education, community-based social marketing, participatory research
Trust built through hiring staff reflective of community, using local leaders
Culturally and linguistically relevant outreach essential
Feedback mechanisms and iterative program design associated with higher satisfaction

barriers_to_access.description: Multiple overlapping barriers limit program access
key_points: Financial: upfront costs, lack of credit, inability to capture rebates/tax credits
Structural/policy: regulatory constraints, split incentives, limited eligibility
Technical: old housing stock, pre-upgrade repair needs, infrastructure limitations
Trust/communication: distrust of government, language barriers, lack of awareness
Systemic: historic disinvestment, redlining, exclusion, environmental injustice
